instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Came in with no power and noticed <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> getting hot on bench power supply. When <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is replaced board boots again from bench power supply but when genuine charger is used <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> shorts out and heats up again.

Board is spotless.

Not sure what to try next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Original charger shouldn't cause such problem; even using 85W instead of 45W.
<CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is powered from <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, which comes from <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (via <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>).

Check all voltages with <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> removed.
